Package infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel

Class TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel.TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, TransferEntropyCalculator, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel
    public class TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel
extends TransferEntropyCommon
implements TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate

    Computes the differential transfer entropy (TE) between two multivariate double[][] time-series of observations using box-kernel estimation. See Schreiber below for the definition of transfer entropy, Lizier et al. (2011) for the extension to multivariate source and destination, and and Lizier et al. (2008) for the definition of local transfer entropy. For details on box-kernel estimation, see Kantz and Schreiber (below).

    TE was defined by Schreiber (below). This estimator is realised here by extending TransferEntropyCommon.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel().
    • Further properties are available, see setProperty(String, String);
    • Additional initialise(int), initialise(int, double) options;
    • Additional utility methods for computing other information-theoretic values are available here (e.g. computeAverageLocalOfObservationsWithCorrection()) which can be called after all observations are supplied.

    TODO Implement dynamic correlation exclusion with multiple observation sets. (see the way this is done in Plain calculator).

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J.T. Lizier, J. Heinzle, A. Horstmann, J.-D. Haynes, M. Prokopenko, "Multivariate information-theoretic measures reveal directed information structure and task relevant changes in fMRI connectivity", Journal of Computational Neuroscience, vol. 30, pp. 85-107, 2011.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    • H. Kantz and T. Schreiber, "Nonlinear Time Series Analysis" (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, MA, 1997).
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName,
                        java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception

        Set properties for the kernel TE calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • KERNEL_WIDTH_PROP_NAME (legacy value is EPSILON_PROP_NAME) -- kernel width to be used in the calculation. If normalise is set, then this is a number of standard deviations; otherwise it is an absolute value. Default is DEFAULT_KERNEL_WIDTH.
        • NORMALISE_PROP_NAME -- whether to normalise the incoming variables to mean 0, standard deviation 1, or not (default false). Sets normalise.
        • DYN_CORR_EXCL_TIME_NAME -- a dynamics exclusion time window (see Kantz and Schreiber), default is 0 which means no dynamic exclusion window.
        • FORCE_KERNEL_COMPARE_TO_ALL -- whether to force the underlying kernel estimators to compare each data point to each other (or else allow it to use optimisations).
        • any valid properties for TransferEntropyCommon.setProperty(String, String).

        Note that dynamic correlation exclusion (set with DYN_CORR_EXCL_TIME_NAME) may have unexpected results if multiple observation sets have been added. This is because multiple observation sets are treated as though they are from a single time series, so observations from near the end of observation set i will be excluded from comparison to observations near the beginning of observation set (i+1).

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Overrides:
        setProperty in class TransferEntropyCommon
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • setObservations

        public void setObservations​(double[][] source,
                            double[][] destination)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF for the channel measure. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.

        The supplied series are certainly (multivariate) time-series for time-series measures such as transfer entropy, however may be simply a set of separate observations for the mutual information without a time interpretation.

        Specified by:
        setObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        source - series of multivariate observations for the source variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        destination - series of multivariate observations for the destination variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations​(double[] source,
                            double[] destination)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Add observations of a single-dimensional source and destination pair. This call is only allowed if the source and destination dimensions are set to 1.

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with. It is intended to be called multiple times, and must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(). Call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Overrides:
        addObservations in class TransferEntropyCommon
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if sourceDimensions and destDimensions were not both initialised to 1 in ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.initialise(int, int)

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations​(double[] source,
                            double[] destination,
                            int startTime,
                            int numTimeSteps)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Add sub-series of observations of a single-dimensional source and destination pair. This call is only allowed if the source and destination dimensions are set to 1.

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with, as a subset of the supplied arrays. It is intended to be called multiple times, and must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(). Call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Overrides:
        addObservations in class TransferEntropyCommon
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        startTime - first index to take observations on
        numTimeSteps - number of steps from and including startTime to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

                            int numTimeSteps)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate

        Adds a new sub-series of observations to update the PDFs with - is intended to be called multiple times. Must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(); call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        source - series of multivariate observations for the source variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        destination - series of multivariate observations for the destination variable (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        startTime - first index to take observations on
        numTimeSteps - number of steps from and including startTime to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • finaliseAddObservations

        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.
        Specified by:
        finaliseAddObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous

        the estimate of the measure (in bits or nats, depending on the estimator)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservationsWithCorrection

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservationsWithCorrection()
                                                       throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the average Transfer Entropy for the previously supplied observations, using the Grassberger correction for the point count k: log_e(k) ~= digamma(k).

        HOWEVER -- Kaiser and Schreiber, Physica D 166 (2002) pp. 43-62 suggest (on p. 57) that for the TE though the adverse correction of the bias correction is worse than the correction itself (because the probabilities being multiplied/divided are not independent), so recommend not to use this method.

        As such, it is implemented here for testing purposes only.

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations()

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon

        Computes the local values of the implemented channel measure, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local channel measure values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations​(double[][] source,
                                                      double[][] destination)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the local measure values for each of the supplied samples in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        I'm not convinced it is such a good idea to do this on data not used for the PDFs with a kernel estimator (since one can now get kernel estimates for probabilities of zero now) but I've implemented it anyway. I guess getting kernel estimates of zero here is no different than what can occur with dynamic correlation exclusion.
        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable (indexed by time or observation index then variable number)
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable (indexed by time or observation index then variable number) Length must match newSourceObservations, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the series of local channel measure values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations​(double[] newSourceObservations,
                                                      double[] newDestObservations)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Computes local values for observations of a single-dimensional source and destination pair. This call is only allowed if the source and destination dimensions are set to 1. Compute the local measure values for each of the supplied samples in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        I'm not convinced it is such a good idea to do this on data not used for the PDFs with a kernel estimator (since one can now get kernel estimates for probabilities of zero now) but I've implemented it anyway. I guess getting kernel estimates of zero here is no different than what can occur with dynamic correlation exclusion.
        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        newSourceObservations - series of observations for the source variable (indexed by time or observation index)
        newDestObservations - series of observations for the destination variable (indexed by time or observation index) Length must match newSourceObservations, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the series of local channel measure values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance​(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an empirical (bootstrapped) distribution of what the given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations methods etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the empirical distribution of measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance​(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an empirical (bootstrapped) distribution of what the given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done MI, conditional MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations methods etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by a call to getNumObservations() for the given measure) containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the empirical distribution of measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where e.g. the newOrderings don't supply arrays of the correct length matching the number of observations that we have.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeLocalActiveOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalActiveOfPreviousObservations()
                                                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Computes the local active info storage for the previous supplied observations.

        Where more than one time series has been added, the array contains the local values for each tuple in the order in which they were added.

        If there was only a single time series added, the array contains k zero values before the local values. (This means the length of the return array is the same as the length of the input time series).

        Precondition: The user must have computed the local TEs first for these vectors.

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorViaMutualInfo.computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()

      • computeLocalActiveUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalActiveUsingPreviousObservations​(double[][] destination)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Computes local active info storage for the given observations, using the previously supplied observations to compute the PDFs.

        I don't think it's such a good idea to do this for continuous variables (e.g. where one can get kernel estimates for probabilities of zero now) but I've implemented it anyway. I guess getting kernel estimates of zero here is no different than what can occur with dynamic correlation exclusion.

        Precondition: The user must have computed the local TEs first for these vectors

        Parameters:
        source -
        destination -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorViaMutualInfo.computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[])
